node.text:
This week, we explore how we grow veggies on the @iss and how instruments on the station help track plant health on the ground. 

Snacktime with NASA digs into the science behind what’s on your plate from a tasty cheese board, to seafood, to fresh produce, to chips and dip. 

Food can bring us a sense of home, and it connects people all around the world. With observations from space and aircraft, combined with high-end computer modeling, NASA scientists work together with partner agencies, organizations, farmers, ranchers, fishermen, and decision makers to understand the relationship between the Earth system and the environments that provide us food.

Music: Cakes & Buns Underscore by Lewis Reed [UPM], Light and Playful Instrumental by Lo Brutto [UPM]

Credit: NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center
Katie Jepson (KBR): Lead Producer
Kathleen Gaeta (AIMM): Host
Matt Romeyn (NASA/KSC): Lead Scientist
Christine Lee (JPL): Lead Scientist
Katy Mersman (KBR): Producer
Kathleen Gaeta (AIMM): Producer

This video can be freely shared and downloaded at https://svs.gsfc.nasa.gov/13910. While the video in its entirety can be shared without permission, the music and some individual imagery may have been obtained through permission and may not be excised or remixed in other products. Specific details on such imagery may be found here: https://svs.gsfc.nasa.gov.

If you liked this video, subscribe to the NASA Goddard YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/NASAGoddard

🧀 This week, we’re making a cheese board and talking about a crucial ingredient for almost everything we eat: water!

Snacktime with NASA digs into the science behind what’s on your plate from a tasty cheese board, to seafood, to fresh produce, to chips and dip. 

Food can bring us a sense of home, and it connects people all around the world. With observations from space and aircraft, combined with high-end computer modeling, NASA scientists work together with partner agencies, organizations, farmers, ranchers, fishermen, and decision makers to understand the relationship between the Earth system and the environments that provide us food.

Music credit: ”Tiny Creatures" and "Cakes & Buns" from Universal Production Music

Credit: NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center
Katy Mersmann (KBR): Lead Producer
Kathleen Gaeta (AIMM): Host
Matthew Rodell (NASA GSFC): Lead Scientist
Katie Jepson (KBR): Producer
Lauren Ward (KBR): Producer

node.text:
This week, Snack Time with NASA teamed up with @nasa_es!

Snack Time with NASA digs into the science behind what’s on your plate from a tasty cheese board, to seafood, to fresh produce, to chips and dip.

Food can bring us a sense of home, and it connects people all around the world. With observations from space and aircraft, combined with high-end computer modeling, NASA scientists work together with partner agencies, organizations, farmers, ranchers, fishermen, and decision makers to understand the relationship between the Earth system and the environments that provide us food.

---------------

La hora del snack con la NASA enseña la ciencia que hay detrás de lo que hay en el plato.

La comida nos hace sentirnos en casa y conectados a personas de todo el mundo. Con observaciones desde el espacio y la aviación, combinadas con modelos informáticos de alto nivel, los científicos de la NASA colaboran con organizaciones, agricultores, ganaderos, pescadores y miembros de la comunidad para comprender la relación entre el sistema terrestre y nuestra comida.

---------------

Music credit: “Tea on the Lawn Underscore” by Paul Reeves [PRS], UPM
"Sunlights and Coconuts" by Damien Deshayes [SACEM], UPM
"Cheeky Chops" by Matthew Anderson [PRS] and Florian Moenks [GEMA], UPM
"Creatures of the Deep" by Sam Dodson [PRS], UPM
Credit: NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center
Kathleen Gaeta (GSFC AIMMS): Lead Producer
Katherine Jepson (GSFC KBR): Lead Producer
Jocelyn Argueta (JPL): Host
Dr. Laura Lorenzoni (NASA): Lead Scientist
Jefferson Beck (GSFC KBR): Lead Editor

If you liked this video, subscribe to the NASA Goddard YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/NASAGoddard

Follow NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center

node.text:
Snacktime with NASA digs into the science behind what’s on your plate from a tasty cheese board, to seafood, to fresh produce, to chips and dip. 

Food can bring us a sense of home, and it connects people all around the world. With observations from space and aircraft, combined with high-end computer modeling, NASA scientists work together with partner agencies, organizations, farmers, ranchers, fishermen, and decision makers to understand the relationship between the Earth system and the environments that provide us food.

Music credit: “Happy Accident” from Universal Production Music

Credit: @nasagoddard
Kathleen Gaeta(GSFC AIMMS): Lead Producer
Jocelyn Argueta (@nasajpl): Host
Dr. Inbal Becker-Reshef (NASA Harvest): Lead Scientist
Lauren Ward (GSFC): Lead Writer

This video is public domain and along with other supporting visualizations can be downloaded from NASA Goddard's Scientific Visualization Studio at: https://svs.gsfc.nasa.gov/13899

If you liked this video, subscribe to the NASA Goddard YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/NASAGoddard

Follow NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center: @nasagoddard

node.title: Snack time with NASA: Chips & Dip

node.text:
Many aspects of human life have been impacted by #COVID19. Lockdown restrictions on a global scale have limited human activity. Our featured challenge “Environmental Justice During the COVID-19 Pandemic”, presented participants with an opportunity to use Earth observation data to explore how human activity in communities of minority, low-income, tribal, and indigenous populations have changed as a result of COVID-19.

Join participants around the world on June 23-29 for the #EODashHack in partnership with @nasa, @esa_earth, and @jaxajp.

eodashboardhackathon.org

node.text:
The COVID-19 pandemic offered an unprecedented opportunity to look at changes in the Earth system in response to reduced human activity.

Our featured challenge, “Looking at the Big Picture” presents participants with an opportunity to understand changes in Earth’s interconnected systems. Explore water and air quality data, river discharge and precipitation data through the EO Dashboard.

Join @nasa, @esa_earth, @jaxajp, and participants around the world for the #EODashHack on June 23-29 to develop tools to better understand these changes.

www.eodashboardhackathon.org

node.title: Looking at the big picture and learning from the past

node.text:
In July 2017, the Larsen C ice shelf along the eastern coast of the Antarctic Peninsula spawned A-68A—one of the planet’s largest icebergs on record. The berg disintegrated in April 2021, ending a more than 2500-kilometer journey that spanned almost four years. This video highlights some of the iceberg’s notable moments, from its initial break amid winter darkness, to its sunlit debut, to its close encounter with a remote island.

The melting of A-68A won’t directly contribute to sea level rise. But satellite images like these—captured throughout the ice’s rifting, calving, and subsequent drift—will help scientists study the natural life cycles of Antarctic ice shelves and icebergs yet to come.

node.title: Tracking an Antarctic Iceberg’s Epic Journey

node.text: From space, it’s easy to see how Earth connects us all. How ecosystems as different as the Sahara Desert and the Amazon Rainforest are linked. How changes in one part of the world will be felt around the planet. This #EarthDay, we’re examining how we're #ConnectedByEarth.

node.text: We started this tournament with 32 photos taken from the @iss and @nasaastronauts, and now are down to 8. All of the number 1 seeds are gone. Two number 8 seeds are dominating their groups. Catch up on the biggest upsets, upcoming interesting match-ups, and predictions for the finals.

node.text:
Globally, 2020 was the hottest year on record, effectively tying 2016, the previous record. Overall, Earth’s average temperature has risen more than 2 degrees F since the 1880s. The effects of rising temperatures are felt around the world.

Heat and the energy it carries drive our planet: winds, weather, droughts, floods and more are expressions of heat. The right amount of heat even helps make life on Earth possible. But too much heat changes how our planet’s systems act.

2020 was a year of extremes, with record-breaking hurricane and fire seasons. Higher surface temperatures and more heat in the climate system can fuel different extreme events, directly and indirectly, like increasing tropical storm intensity.

This year, we saw record-setting fires in Australia and the western U.S., after years of high temperature and drought set the stage. Smoke from fires in both regions reached so high into the atmosphere that it formed clouds. In Siberia, unusually high temperatures drove fires burning peat soil -- decomposed organic materials -- that stores a lot of carbon. Peat fires release vast amounts of carbon into the atmosphere, potentially leading to even more warming.

The Arctic region is warming three times faster than the rest of the planet. Arctic sea ice reached a near-record low extent this year. 

A warm Atlantic ocean helped fuel a record-breaking hurricane season, with 30 named storms. This year, a record 12 storms made landfall in the United States. 

At @nasa, we work with our partners at @noaa to study our planet and the ways it’s changing. We also study the causes and effects of climate change from space, with a unique view of increasing carbon in the atmosphere.

#nasa #climatechange #climate #earth #earthscience #temperatureupdate #temperature

node.title: A Look Back: How Heat Shaped 2020

node.text:
Global sea level is rising about an eighth of an inch per year, and at a faster and faster rate. People are already feeling the impacts, as seemingly small increments of sea level rise become big problems along coastlines worldwide. 

About two-thirds of global sea level rise comes from melting ice sheets and glaciers, including those in Antarctica and Greenland as well as smaller glaciers in Alaska, High Mountain Asia, South America, and the Canadian Arctic.

The other third is due to expansion of the water itself. When water molecules get warmer, the atoms in those molecules vibrate faster, expanding the volume they take up. It’s an infinitesimally small change in the size of a single water molecule, but compound all the water molecules in all of Earth’s oceans and it adds up.

We’ll be sharing more about the processes driving sea level rise, the effects, and how @NASA studies them all from space and closer to the ground in anticipation of the launch of Sentinel-6 Michael Freilich. Follow along at nasa.gov/sea-level-rise-2020. 

#SeeingTheSeas #SeaLevelRise #Ocean #NASA #Satellite #Launch #Space #sentinel6

node.title: Tribute to NASA Earth Trailblazer Michael Freilich

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by NASA Earth Observatory on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'CELEBRATING THE EO DASHBOARD HAcKaTHoN Global Winners VASA esa XAXA'.

node.text:
Congratulations from @NASA, @esa_earth, and @jaxajp to the EO Dashboard Hackathon Global Winners 🎉! Are you curious about what game plans the Global Winners had for their #EODashHack projects? To celebrate our Global Winners we have invited the winning hackathon team members to answer questions about the Earth Observation Dashboard Hackathon.

Swipe ➡️ to hear from the Global Winners of the EO Dashboard Hackathon as they share their thoughts and favorite things about EO Dashboard!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by NASA Earth Observatory on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'CELEBRATING THE EO DASHBOARD HAcKaTHoN Global Winners VASA esa XAXA'.

Photo by NASA Earth Observatory on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'EO DASHBOARD HACKATHON What was one thing that was surprising to you during the hackathon? Is there anything new you learned from the competition? NASA o esa XAXA'.

node.text:
Satellite Observes Power Outages in New Orleans

Three days after Hurricane Ida brought fierce wind, rain, and storm surges to Louisiana, large swaths of the state are enduring electric power blackouts due to downed lines and damaged transmission towers. According to news sources, many people are also going without access to running water and gasoline due to damaged infrastructure.

A team of scientists from NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center and the Universities Space Research Association (USRA) has mapped the outages using satellite data. The images here show nighttime lights data acquired on August 9 and 31 by the Suomi NPP satellite. The base maps make use of data collected by the Landsat 8 satellite.

“The imagery is surprisingly cloud-free. It usually would take at least 48 hours for skies to clear up enough after an event like this,” added Miguel Román, a USRA scientist and leader of the Black Marble Project. “At this aftermath stage, Black Marble imagery is capturing a lot of diesel-power/backup generation, which utilities do not monitor.”

By the morning of September 1, 2021, more than 985,000 customers were reported without power in Louisiana according to data compiled by PowerOutage.US from publicly accessible sources. (The total counts homes and businesses, not people.) Another 33,000 customers were without power in Mississippi.

VIIRS has a low-light sensor—the day/night band—that measures light emissions and reflections. This capability has made it possible to distinguish the intensity, types, and sources of lights and to observe how they change. The data are then processed by the Black Marble team to account for changes in the landscape (such as flooding), the atmosphere, and the Moon phase, and to filter out stray light from sources that are not electric lights.

Precision is critical for studies with night lights. Raw, unprocessed images can be misleading because moonlight, clouds, pollution, seasonal vegetation—even the position of the satellite—can change how light is reflected and can distort observations.

https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/images/148777/satellite-observes-power-outages-in-new-orleans

node.text:
Thirty-six years ago, an astronaut aboard the Space Shuttle Discovery focused a camera lens on South America’s Paraná River. This southward-looking panorama shows the point where the Paraná flows into northern Argentina, then bends south, and finally reaches the Atlantic Ocean at the River Plate estuary (top left). For scale, the distance from Asunción, the Paraguayan capital, to the Argentine capital of Buenos Aires is more than 1000 kilometers (600 miles).

This photo shows a very large ‘inland delta’ where the Paraná River has spread out laterally to form a huge, triangular surface (outlined in gray) that measures 425 kilometers (265 miles) from the apex to the most distant point near La Paz. The entire surface of the delta—known to geologists as a megafan—is covered by numerous channels showing where the Paraná used to flow. The channels can be seen radiating across the delta from the apex.

The photo was taken with a Hasselblad film camera—common in the days before astronauts switched to digital cameras—and before wide views were easily obtainable from the International Space Station. It remains one of the best images to demonstrate megafan landscapes. Two other megafans are partly visible: the lower 100 kilometers (60 miles) of the Pilcomayo and Bermejo megafans. The Pilcomayo megafan is the largest on the planet at 705 kilometers in length.

https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/images/148755/the-parana-megafan

node.text:
Hurricane Ida Batters Louisiana

Exactly 16 years after Katrina made landfall, another major hurricane blew into southern Louisiana. Around noon on August 29, 2021, #HurricaneIda came ashore at Port Fourchon with sustained winds of 150 miles (240 kilometers) per hour and a central pressure of 930 millibars. Preliminary reports suggest it is the fifth strongest hurricane (based on wind speed) ever to make landfall in the continental U.S.

At 2:50 a.m. Central Daylight Time on August 30, the Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS) on the Suomi NPP satellite acquired a nighttime view (above) of Hurricane Ida. On the morning of August 29, the NOAA GOES-16 satellite acquired data for an animation of the menacing eyewall approaching the coast.

https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/images/148767/hurricane-ida-batters-louisiana

node.text:
It’s #worldmosquitoday 🦟 and the @globeprogram 🌎 would like to invite you all to take part in their current #mosquitochallenge.  Researchers from university teams sponsored by @nasa and the @nsfgov are asking for your photos 📱of mosquito habitats 💦🪣, the surrounding land cover 🏞🌆, and mosquito larvae (if you can) to use in their #AI research 🖥. This research will help pinpoint mosquito types and the potential for disease outbreaks around the world 🗺. All you have to do is download ⬇️the free GLOBE Observer app (observer.globe.gov), create an account, and start taking observations using the in-app tools. More details on the challenge can be found at: observer.globe.gov/mosquito-challenge 

Thank you to Karlene of @usouthflorida — and a member of one of the research teams at the Carney Lab — for creating this reel for us. 

#mosquito #diseaseprevention #machinelearning #artificialintelligence #NASAGO #citsci #citizenscience #zika #zikavirus #malaria

node.text:
Is it just us or are we really ✨photogenic✨? 

Over the last 60 years, @NASAAstronauts have taken more than 1.5 million photos of Earth from space. More than just beautiful, these photos help record how Earth is changing over time, including human-caused changes and dynamic events such as hurricanes, floods & volcanic eruptions. 

#WorldPhotographyDay
 
📸:
1. A compilation of dozens of long-exposure photographs taken from space turns stars into stunning rings and city lights and fires into colorful streaks.
 
2. Astronaut Andrew Morgan used a fisheye lens to capture the intersection of two continents.
 
3. Thailand and Cambodia have distinctly different hues at night compared to nearby seas.
 
4. Sunlight traces the mouth of one of Asia’s great rivers—a major artery for commercial and sediment transport.
 
5. Uninhabited Atlasov Island rises above the clouds and the Sea of Okhotsk.

6. The smallest country in mainland Africa hugs its namesake river.

node.text:
This week, we explore how we grow veggies on the @iss and how instruments on the station help track plant health on the ground. 

Snacktime with NASA digs into the science behind what’s on your plate from a tasty cheese board, to seafood, to fresh produce, to chips and dip. 

Food can bring us a sense of home, and it connects people all around the world. With observations from space and aircraft, combined with high-end computer modeling, NASA scientists work together with partner agencies, organizations, farmers, ranchers, fishermen, and decision makers to understand the relationship between the Earth system and the environments that provide us food.

Music: Cakes & Buns Underscore by Lewis Reed [UPM], Light and Playful Instrumental by Lo Brutto [UPM]

Credit: NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center
Katie Jepson (KBR): Lead Producer
Kathleen Gaeta (AIMM): Host
Matt Romeyn (NASA/KSC): Lead Scientist
Christine Lee (JPL): Lead Scientist
Katy Mersman (KBR): Producer
Kathleen Gaeta (AIMM): Producer

While the video in its entirety can be shared without permission, the music and some individual imagery may have been obtained through permission and may not be excised or remixed in other products. Specific details on such imagery may be found here: https://svs.gsfc.nasa.gov.

Looking for some #LandsatCraft inspiration? Follow along to learn how to make a Landsat-inspired collage, and then share your creation with us!
We’re preparing to launch Landsat 9 with our partners at @usgs this fall. 

#nasa #usgs #landsat #earth #earthfromspace #earthscience

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by NASA Earth Observatory on August 17, 2021.

node.text:
A London Mosaic

This expansive view of the River Thames flowing eastward through the London metropolitan area is a mosaic of 29 overlapping photographs taken by an astronaut looking down from the International Space Station (ISS). A detailed view of London at this scale is seldom achieved from the ISS due to frequently cloudy conditions.

https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/images/148709/a-london-mosaic
